title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer interest-bearing transaction accounts to businesses, permitting up to 24 transfers per month. Additionally, the Act authorizes the payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer interest-bearing transaction accounts to businesses with up to 24 transfers per month. It also authorizes the payment of earnings on reserves held at Federal Reserve Banks, with regulations set by the Board. The curr_chunk discusses the responsibilities of depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regarding the distribution of earnings from balances maintained in Federal reserve banks. It also defines 'depository institution' to include various types of financial entities. The curr_chunk amends the Federal Reserve Act regarding pass-through reserves for member banks and makes technical and conforming amendments to certain sections of the Act. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. It allows for a ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and not less than 8 percent (which may be zero). SEC. 5 deals with the transfer of Federal Reserve surpluses. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer necessary sums to the Board for deposit in the Treasury's general fund. The Board will determine the amount each bank pays in each fiscal year. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, Federal Reserve banks are prohibited from replenishing their surplus funds by the amount transferred under subparagraph (A). Any surplus funds exceeding 3 percent of paid-in capital and surplus of member banks shall be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
